results.title: The Dawns here are quiet = A Zori Zdes Tikhiye
results.creator_credit: Stanislav Rostotsky, G Natanson and Mosfilm
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Films of the great victory 1941-1945”.
Set in WW2, Karelia, northwest Russia, this elegiac war drama is about a small group of female soldiers in training, who are unexpectedly called upon to face a Nazi patrol of paratroopers. The narrative sensitively portrays the women’s camaraderie, as well as their pre-war domestic life, and spousal relationships. A fine ensemble cast heads what is widely regarded as powerful statement about war and society, and the sacrifices of ordinary citizens made in extraordinary times. Based on a true story and adapted from the book by Boris Vasilyev. Also known as “At Dawn its quiet here” and “That Dawn should be peaceful”.

results.title: They fought for their motherland = Oni srazhalis za rodinu
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Films of the great victory 1941-1945”.
Epic film by Soviet filmmaker Sergei Bondarchuk, depicts the skirmishes faced by Russian troops, during the WW2 invasion of Stalingrad by the Germans. Impressive action sequences meticulously recreate the drama, danger, destruction and disorientation of war. Winner of the State Prize of the Russian Federation, 1977.

results.title: The Cranes are flying = Letyat Zhuravli
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Films of the great victory 1941-1945”.
Expressionistic melodrama set in WW2, about a young Russian woman, who believes her lover to have perished in battle. Devastated by grief she falls into a passionless affair with his cousin, who seduces her during an air-raid. Struggling to find meaning amid the tragedies that have befallen her and the calamity of war, she vacillates between despair and hope. Winner of the Palm d’or at Cannes. Stars Tatyana Samoylova in the title role.

results.title: Ballad of a soldier = Ballada o soldate
results.creator_credit: Grigori Chukhrai, M Chernova and Mosfilm
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Films of the great victory 1941-1945”.
Amid the chaos of WW2, a young Russian soldier earns a pass home, for an act of heroism. En route he is detained constantly, as he helps others on their way, managing only the briefest of encounters with his forlorn mother, before returning to active duty. This acclaimed drama speaks of the hardship of war as experienced by the Russian people and of the sadness of separation. It also depicts the sensuality of youth, a theme previously denied Russian filmmakers, but allowed during the “thaw” as it was known, a period in the 1950s of Soviet cinema.

results.title: Destiny of a man = Sudba cheloveka
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Films of the great victory 1941-1945”.
Melancholy and sympathetic view of the tragedies suffered by a family man and WW2 POW survivor. Haunted by his experiences in a concentration camp the man has survived this appalling event by clinging to the hope of reuniting with his wife and child. Directed by, and also starring Sergei Bondarchuk, this was a successful film that with its unstinting humanism, proved the ability of Russian filmmakers to combine cinematic beauty with compassionate sentiment.

results.title: The Star = Zvezda
results.creator_credit: Nikolai Lebedev, Karen Shakhnazarov and Mosfilm
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Films of the great victory 1941-1945”.
Based on the book by Emmanuil Kazakevich, this film focuses on a group of Russian scouts in WW2, aiming to penetrate Nazi communications and thwart a major attack. Echoing the themes of Steven Spielberg’s “Saving Private Ryan” (2000), director Nikolai Lebedev presents war as chaotic, taxing and disorienting. At times quite claustrophobic, the film works best when presenting the dangerously fraught reconnaissance missions undertaken by the unit.

results.title: Torpedo bombers = Torpedonostsy
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Films of the great victory 1941-1945”.
By interspersing historical footage with fictional narrative, this film attempts to present the precarious fighting conditions for WW2 Russian bomber pilots. The filmmaker ably captures the taxing environment in which battles were conducted and the constant danger to those serving in the armed forces. It also depicts the fraught personal lives of the pilots, under strain from wartime conditions. Based on the stories by Yuri German.

group_works.title: The Academy of St Martin in the Fields at Longleat

group_works.title: The Music of Mozart and Haydn
group_works.creator_credit: Dave Heather, Lexi Godfrey, EMI/Parlophone and Klein

results.title: The Music of Mozart and Haydn
results.creator_credit: Dave Heather, Lexi Godfrey, EMI/Parlophone and Klein
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Castles and concerts”.
Set in the magnificent Haydnsaal of the Schloss Esterhazy in Eisenstadt, Austria and in the historic palaces of Vienna, the Polish Chamber Orchestra conducted by Jerzy Maksymiuk perform three beautiful pieces of chamber music by two of Austria’s greatest classical composers, Mozart and Haydn. Includes images of some of Austria’s picturesque landscapes, artworks and amazing palaces and gardens creating an ambient background to the music of the Orchestra. No commentary.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dave Heather, Lexi Godfrey, EMI/Parlophone and Klein

Includes images of some of Austria’s picturesque landscapes, artworks and amazing palaces and gardens creating an ambient background to the music of the Orchestra. No commentary.

group_siblings.title: The Academy of St Martin in the Fields at Longleat
group_siblings.creator_credit: Dave Heather, Martin Wyn Griffith, EMI/Parlophone and Klein

results.title: The Academy of St Martin in the Fields at Longleat
results.creator_credit: Dave Heather, Martin Wyn Griffith, EMI/Parlophone and Klein
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Castles and concerts”.
Set in the idyllic historic Longleat House in Wiltshire, England, this program of popular classics is performed by The Academy of St Martin in the Fields conducted by world-renowned Neville Marriner (also artistic director). Neville Marriner introduces the program and provides a commentary on the history of Longleat House and the music of the great composers of the 17th and 18th centuries. Beautiful images of the Longleat Estate, both interior and exterior, accompany the music to provide an atmospheric re-creation of those earlier centuries.
